This a pretty soft recommend. Its almost a neutral or maybe a soft non-recommendation, but a lot of the issues I have with the game stem from quality of life things that could be improved within a few patches. 

Keeping it simple, Per Aspera is a very pretty game with some really good gameplay and sound design. I spent a lot of the time that I played the game simply looking at the landscape and watching the water or grass slowly spread across the planet. I also found the voice acting to be very refreshing. Troy Baker in particular did a wonderful job as Dr. Nathan Foster and honestly I found myself wishing he would talk [i]more[/i]. The gameplay loop is very enjoyable as well and reminds me a lot of games like Satisfactory or Factorio. Build more mines and factories to expand the base, to find more resources, to build more mines and factories, to support more colonists, to research more things, to build better mines and factories... and also terraform the planet. One of the things that I think is worth mentioning is that I thought it was pretty neat watching how your road system develops. The game will auto-draw roads based on the best possible path between nodes, which ends up giving you some pretty cool spider-web-esque designs. Finally as, far as the story goes, I'd say it's pretty good. Without spoiling anything, it doesn't end up being as straight forward as you might think. Although it seems mostly linear, the game gives you a few options how to steer AMI on her mission to terraform Mars so you don't feel entirely on rails.

All that good stuff being said, allow me to address some of the things I didn't like. I should also mention that I haven't fully completed the story, but that is mostly because of the issues I have with the game. 
Again, keeping it simple, the story comes off as feeling very disjointed once you get into the late game. I ran into multiple times where characters would be conversing with AMI as if they were friends, despite having not yet met them. One good example being where I was pretty well into the endgame, having just made a pretty drastic choice with big implications, only to have a voice communication occur that was very obviously from the early/mid game. This is more than likely due to the open nature of the game, but the mission objectives don't exactly do a good job of pointing you towards where you should go. 
This would be pretty forgiveable if the gameplay held up as well, but frankly it doesn't. Towards the mid game you start noticing that resources aren't being sent where they need to go as efficiently as they should be, thus factories and colonies aren't being supplied, lowering your productivity and research. A fair bit of this can be attributed to poor worker hub layout and a poor understanding of how workers interact with each other, but again the game doesn't really explain it to you that well. So much of it is trial and error, and even then you can only do so much. Hyperloops and road upgrades can help mitigate the logistics crisis you inevitably fall into, but road upgrades are so tedious and the late game so vast, that you eventually just run out of capacity. 
There are also a ton of minor things that irk me. Why can I not paint an area to upgrade my roads? Why can I not upgrade my worker hubs to support more drones? Why can I not choose what areas worker hubs service?  Why is it that building tool tips keep popping up and blocking me while I'm trying to place buildings? What is with the AI building roads at extreme angles and through buildings when it could obviously go straight? And the big one, why do I not get refunded the resources spent upgrading roads when I delete the building they were connected to and, consequently, the roads along with it?

As I said, this game is wonderful. There is a certainly a lot to love about it and I can definitely see this evolving into a series that I come back to over the years. I just think there's some tinkering to be done in the tutorial, story progression, and gameplay department to get it over some of these bumps.

As a final rating, I'd say wait for a sale on this one.

This ludo-narrative dissonance wouldn't be so bad, except the way you progress in the game is tedious.

All resource deposits run out, which means your only survival strategy is to constantly expand. Expanding is critical, as later game projects require too many resources. Setting up secondary bases, and then linking them to your primary base, is all you will do in this game. And the tools for doing that will leave you wanting. You will just power/worker/maintaince/storage walk in a giant line to the base you just slapped down to link them so you can feed your primary base.

Each base you create? It will do the exact same bootstrapping process you had done from the beginning. Every single time. Managing production quotas is impossible, though there are plenty of tools for visualizing how your production is failing. Not much you can do to effect change.

As the game goes on, performance drops, and the number of resources and robots you needs climbs fast. You need to constantly be expanding to afford all the projects, keep your colonists alive, and more. It becomes a real chore.

Here are some improvements that would have a big impact:

1) Remote bases are not fun to manage. Starting with more drones on a new base, linking power over greater distances, and having more starting resources on the new base (that don't need buildings) would reduce the repetition. 

2) I want to set per-region resource min/max, not per base. Once I had 40 bases or more, I don't want to go through each to manually set resources max, or turning off the steel factory at each base that I needed to get that outpost through the bootstrap phase. Being able to define a "region" of linked bases and setting production quotas would help.

3) The grind is too long. You need thousands of carbon, iron, and more resources for various projects. I wasn't even sure the defense network was necessary. The story hinted an attack would come, but once built, the network was never "tested", so it felt pointless. The space elevator was underwhelming for its cost.

4) Space ports should be nameable, and clickable through the mission selector. The dropdown is too small.

5) Managing pop influx was frustrating. You have a small window to remember to cancel more pop from coming in. You can "cheat" this by turning off the space port, forever freezing the colonist ship in place, and also locking up your space port. Just let me set a max pop or something and have the ship make its own trips, or anything than the current way it works which is frustrating.

6) If I have hyperloops, why do colonists take extremely slow airships? Waiting for a colonist ship to spend *months* moving to a new, story required outpost (of which there are many!) is agonizing when I have a globe spanning hyperloop network that can transport water in a few in-game days.

7) Upgrading roads is tedious. If I remove a building in between (so as to free up building slots), the upgraded roads are removed.

8) Terraforming has no in-game benefit or drawback. It doesn't affect wind or solar output (shouldn't more atmosphere make wind turbines better? Solar worse? Should the mirrors make solar better?). Water on the planet isn't drinkable, apparently. Forests and animals aren't food. By the time you can get open air bases or whatever, the game is past its welcome in terms of grind, and the bases before then can support more pop than I can deliver resources to, let alone generate enough water/food/chemicals.

9) Losing pop has no discernible impact on the game. If you starve your people, they just peacefully leave. No impact on the AI whose only job is to...make Mars for humanity. Yes, it makes research slow, but you'll be spending so much time grinding base expansions and other objectives that it doesn't matter. The characters won't even remark on hundreds of pop leaving.

10) The only cool tech in the tree are space elevators and hyperloops. Everything else is underwhelming (or just simply required, and thus neutral). Military tech is the least inspiring. 

11) New-game plus would be wonderful to experience the other stories. For now, it is too much grind.

12) The required amount of sprawl, while obviously carries a strong story component, feels overly forced and annoying. It makes expansion feel necessary only for the story, rather than the stated purpose of your character, which is to terraform. I suppose this ties into the feeling that terraforming is only a goal, and loosely ties into all the events and things happening.

I know I had a lot of criticism to provide, and I really did enjoy my time with the game. But I had hoped for more, and these many flaws prevent me from playing it again, rather than spoiling the experience I had.

The idea of mankind making Mars its second home has been brewing in our collective consciousness. As we finally approach this incredibly milestone, I feel inspired to play in a Martian sandbox. For the last few years; I've been following numerous games as they attempt to capture this concept. I'm sure you all know the usual suspects.

When I find a game is focused on glorified battle I tend to immediately eliminate it. War and killing does not inspire me. I want to imagine a future where human horizons are expanding and I hope we are getting better at doing this without violence. So I'm looking toward the survival against the elements direction. How can mankind use our intelligence and technology to expand our horizons? Similarly I don't want a game where the mechanics get in the way of the sense of wonder and progress.

I have found Per Aspera to be a deeply developed realization of my Mars play dreams; with caveats. There is a constant sense of struggle against the harsh reality of Mars' natural world. The balance between this struggle and the joy that comes from constant "little wins" as you build mines, factories, supply chains, and housing is addictive. Per Aspera is deep enough in the details to keep your brain working, but not so overwhelming that you cannot see the big picture of what you are accomplishing.

By beginning with a fully open planet that is accurately proportioned from topographic data; you begin in awesome desolation and wilderness. By choosing sandbox mode, you actually have the option to start your adventure from anywhere on the planet you desire. If you prefer the story, there is a complex and controversial one that awaits you.

I have to give a huge shoutout to the amazing artists that must have spent years perfecting each building and thousands of animations. Per Aspera allows you to instantly zoom from a single "worker" transport, out to buildings and roadways, all the way back out into space. It feels very much like Google Earth, but with the ability to create the cities and networks you see below you. You can choose to simply lay out your designs from above in an old-school sim city style, but if you take the time to zoom in you can see every building has a lot of character and life in it.

I hope I have made it clear that this game is very ambitious. Here is where the difficulty lies. Compromises must be made to engineer something like this; and compromises are almost always controversial. Here is one example: Building and terraforming Mars is going to take multiple human generations, and the conceit the developers chose was to have you play as an everlasting AI overseeing development from above. This then opened up a story involving AI, Mars, humanity, and the interplay between these. There are twists and turns in this story that are certain to surprise, and will surely please some and frustrate others. 

The amount of complexity necessary to model and manage a functioning system on a planetary scale is high. I feel like the developers have generally pulled this off, but there are certainly bugs. Multiple patches have been forthcoming in the weeks since release, and we are told these will continue in the new year. There will be periods of frustration for most players when playing even the latest release. If you can find the patience to work through these frustrations, they do not break the game. I have found that I could work around any issues with enough patience and creativity. The patches so far have made progress on fixing the most frustrating issues. There are also reasonable limits on the number of structures that can extend around the planet. You cannot fill the surface of Mars with cities at this time; but you can create world circumnavigating arteries and infrastructure. This may be an opportunity for the developers to improve and expand the game's capabilities in the future.

You will need to enjoy sim city type games to enjoy this game. There will be periods of hours where you will be planning and managing resources similarly to those style games. But I feel this makes sense, and fits well with the Mars story. Humanity's expansion beyond Earth is likely to be a lot more about managing resources and supply chains than anything else. Per Aspera does a good job making this side of things fun. The developers constantly mix things up with new exploration and terraforming objectives. Of all the sim city style games; this is the first since the very original that truly sucked me in for endless hours.

I am very impressed with this game, and believe it will become well loved over time. I certainly enjoyed both the story and sandbox modes. The game is also reasonably priced in comparison to its depth and replayability. It is clear the amount of art and development work that went into Per Aspera is on par with much higher priced games. 

If you are excited about mankind's expansion to Mars; Per Aspera is a wonderful experience that will likely pull you in for many hours.

I highly recommend Per Aspera.

Aside from these mechanical issues, it feels like the narrative is pretty well-tuned at the beginning of the game, but again things fall apart later on. Per Aspera is my new favourite Mars game. This game has the colony building of Surviving Mars, all be it without the need to micromanage individual colonists, but with all the science behind terraforming the red planet. It has the story element of many a good adventure game, and it almost feels like you are seeing swings towards destruction or coexistence. I won’t give the story away but you play the role of a super intelligent machine named AMI and are both asked questions about and amass thoughts on your role in terraforming Mars alongside the role of the human colonists. There is obviously much influence gained from films like 2001 and it is nicely done in game.

[u]Basic Premise[/u]

Per Aspera, from Tlön Industries,  is a colony management sim based on Mars in which you are terraforming the planet sometime in the late 2100s or early 2200s (the game may have said but I missed it). The game has a huge back story and lore foundation that makes for great reading and gets you right in to the setting of the game.

Per Aspera is set on the most beautiful map of Mars I have ever seen in game. It might just be the most beautiful map I have seen in a game. You can zoom out and scan the entire surface of Mars, complete with all the labels of the area names of the red planet (Terra Sabaea, Elysium Planitia, Valles Marineris and Olympus Mons etc) and including a large number of lore information tags that show where past missions to Mars have been centred on in the universe that has been created for Per Aspera.

The map is complete with elevations and looks absolutely fantastic when you pan or flip the map around. It is a work of art.

As I said, you control an artificial intelligence called AMI and your job is to terraform the planet. To do that you start out by creating a basic infrastructure composed of mining and manufacture with elements ranging from carbon, aluminium and steel to water, chemicals and polymers. This is combined with the need to manage the logistics of the mission via management of power, drones, maintenance and resource scanning. You will build hubs to allow expanding a network of worker drones, maintenance depots to keep your network working at full ability and power it with solar panels and wind farms.

The next step is obviously to bring humans to Mars. They arrive via a huge spaceport and colonise the colonies and research bases you build. Research bases can be built on past colonisation attempts that are found via the scanning tools given to you.

Eventually you will start to research new technologies and begin the terraforming of the planet, but I have only just reached that point. It takes time to complete the setup; the mining, the manufacturing and the transporting of colonists, but this stage is far from boring.

[u]Aesthetics[/u]

Whilst Per Aspera doesn’t feature ground breaking graphics, the game is very, very pretty. The style is that of a sort of line drawn pencil sketches, but I am no artist so there is probably a better description. As I said above, the map is stunning and shows the terrain of Mars fantastically well.

When you build buildings little roads crawl across the map to connect your main hub to these new structures. However, the star attraction is how the game simulates the AI working on the layout of her domain. When you place a building blue, almost circuit-like, lines emanate from surrounding structures to find the best route for the roads that will spread across the Martian landscape. This means that roads will follow the terrain in a way that makes for the most efficient transport of resources. It really is quite beautiful.

The terrain is mapped by the use of contour lines and shading of the map to denote height and depth of land. When panning the map you can see the craters and hills of Mars in lovely detail. Zooming around further you can find the areas that will clearly become the future seas of Mars. Zooming in to Olympus Mons is great. I believe I saw the bird dream (music reference). 

[u]The UI[/u]

When I first watched this game on You Tube about a week ago (it has been on my wishlist for ages though) the poster of the video said that the UI could do with more tooltips. Maybe that has been rectified but I have no major issues with the UI. It has a lovely technical style to it, and is crisp and well laid out. If I had one suggestion to make to the developers then I would ask for more detail in the tool tips when the resources are hovered over. I would like a detailed list for where resources are needed. Currently you only have a text outline of how much of a resource is produced and how much is needed.

Taking inspiration from a game like Cities: Skylines, it would be great if the game had a map mode that showed resource production sites and lines on the road grid that show where that resource is going. It is not always fully evident how much of a resource is at each structure and where that resource is needed. You need to learn the resources to make things simpler. There are also no mouseovers of what the resources are on the building panel; just the icons. Once you learn those icons things are great and you will build at liberty.

Really, though, the game just flows on regardless. The resource bar shows clearly how many resources you have and you can see where bottlenecks are. It could just do with some fleshing out and more tools for the user. Per Aspera is far from the only game where a user might request a few more quality of life tools and the game doesn’t suffer horrendously for a few wants, so this is not a damning of the work of Tlön Industries. It is just suggestions.

I do like the map modes that are present in the game. They are lovely overlays that show such things as your traffic network, maintenance range and resources.

My issues are minor really though.

[u]Conclusion[/u]

What I have outlined so far is just the basics of the game really. There seems to be so much more to the game and I will let anyone that is already interested explore the game for themselves. The music is an example of this. It is both futuristic and ambient. I found myself tapping my foot when the music centred around human colonists started playing.

I have currently put seven hours in to Per Aspera and I have enjoyed every second. I am finding the going easy currently, and I am playing on the hardest difficulty. I restarted once when I overbuilt and ran out of starting electronics, but if you follow the missions (that the game calls directives) then you shouldn’t fall in to the same trap as me. I tend to push colony sims often because I have played so very many of them. I can see where the game will become more of a challenge and how things will fail if you are not organised and prepared for humans.

There is also a random element regarding how many resource patches you find. I like a degree of randomness to the game, and in Per Aspera it is not over-burdening or game damaging.

To finish I will say I really love the story element regarding AMI so far. I love the way AMI poses her thoughts and how the game lets you decide her answers to the questions she poses to herself or those posed by the humans in the game. I won’t spoil anything but suffice it to say the story element is wonderfully incorporated in to the game.

After seven hours I just find myself wishing that nominations for the Steam Awards for this year were not finished. Per Aspera is an outstanding little game and easily deserves to be recognised in 2020. I am very much going to enjoy exploring further my terraforming mission of Mars.

Now back to looking after my little humans. AMI out.

[i]Yes, what I am saying is go get this game. If you have any love of Mars centred games, colony builders and science fiction then getting Per Aspera is a no-brainer. A+[/i]

* Chemicals. For what reason are these things so prominently located in flooded zones?
* AI. For attempting to make a game about managing resources and economy, the sophistication of resource routing and management doesn't remotely compare to Mindustry.
